column3:
re-ACK 1c9255c7dd2d4f12bfb508bcc8d123a6354d8842

Checked the disassembly with `-O0`:
```
00000000000c0834 <CMessageHeader::CMessageHeader()>:
   c0834:       f3 0f 1e fa             endbr64 
   c0838:       55                      push   %rbp
   c0839:       48 89 e5                mov    %rsp,%rbp
   c083c:       48 83 ec 20             sub    $0x20,%rsp
   c0840:       48 89 7d
For reference, from https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/array_initialization\n\n> All array elements that are not initialized explicitly are zero-initialized.

Code review ACK 1c9255c7dd2d4f12bfb508bcc8d123a6354d8842\n\nLooking at the code I noticed both `pchCommand`, `pchMessageStart` are char arrays.  There is a memcpy done from `MessageStartChars` (unsigned char array) to `pchMessageStart`, and some architectures specify `char` as signed.  May be a case for explicitly making them unsigned char arrays?
I have a patchset to remove `char`, but haven't pushed it yet

> Looking at the code I noticed both pchCommand, pchMessageStart are char arrays. \n\nAnother good point. There are only very few places where bare 'char' is a good choice. But let's leave it for a future PR.
Right, padding is already zero üëç good catch
Removed and updated the comment above. Thanks.

We could also change the type here to `std::string` or `std::span` instead of a loose pointer, at some point and clean up the loop (oh and rename the argument to `message_type` maybe instead of command, when we're at it). No need to do so in this PR though.
